title: Air pollution still plagues nearly half of Americans. That does a number on our health

title: Five cards China holds in a trade war with the US
snippets: From rare earths to billions in US debt, here's what China has in its arsenal - and how strong they are.

summary: China possesses significant assets that bolster its global position, including extensive reserves of rare earth metals crucial for technology and manufacturing, as well as holding a substantial portion of US debt, amounting to billions of dollars. These assets are key elements of China's economic and strategic strength on the international stage.

The T-Breds are hopeful that celebration was the first of many. The Class AAAA playoffs start next week, and South Aiken will be one of the favorites to bring home a state title. ...
titles: Deep, talented South Aiken boys' tennis team poised for playoff run
summary: On April 23, the South Aiken boys' tennis team celebrated Senior Night, honoring six of its 12 players before their graduation. The event marked the beginning of a hopeful period for the team as they enter the Class AAAA playoffs next week. South Aiken is considered a favorite to win the state title, reflecting their strong performance and potential as the postseason approaches.

title: S&P 500 Gains and Losses Today: Tech Stocks Jump as Trump Softens Stance on Fed and Trade
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • The S&P 500 advanced 1.7% on Wednesday, April 23, as comments from the White House pointed to stability at the Fed and the possibility of easing trade tensions.
  • Antenna and high-speed cable manufacturer Amphenol reported strong quarterly results, and its shares pushed higher.
  • Enphase Energy shares dropped after the solar technology firm missed quarterly estimates and indicated that tariffs could weigh on its upcoming performance.


Major U.S. equities indexes pushed higher after President Trump indicated that he does not intend to fire Jerome Powell from his role as Federal Reserve chair. White House officials also indicated that the U.S. could adopt a more measured approach to tariffs on imports from China, suggesting a potential easing of trade tensions between the world's two largest economies.

The S&P 500 added 1.7% in the midweek trading session, while the Dow closed 1.1% higher. The tech-heavy Nasdaq soared 2.5%. 

Amphenol (APH), a manufacturer of antennas and high-speed electronic cables, topped revenue and adjusted earnings per share (EPS) estimates in its first-quarter earnings report. The company also provided an upbeat forecast for the current quarter, noting opportunities across end markets and highlighting how innovation and strategic acquisitions have helped expand its product offering. Amphenol shares surged 8.2% to secure the top performance in the S&P 500 on Wednesday.

The technology sector outperformed on Wednesday, bolstered by increased optimism for improvements in the U.S.-China trade relationship. Super Micro Computer (SMCI) announced an expansion of its collaboration with Japanese tech firm Fujitsu, which will deploy a new Supermicro server as part of its large language model (LLM) project. Supermicro shares jumped 7.6%.

Meanwhile, Palantir Technologies (PLTR) shares gained 7.3%. The data analytics software firm said it will partner with defense contractor Northrop Grumman (NOC) to develop combat vehicles that leverage artificial intelligence (AI) technology. Northrop Grumman shares edged 1.9% higher on Wednesday, marking a minor recovery from the heavy decline posted in the prior session following a lackluster earnings report.

Shares of solar technology firm Enphase Energy (ENPH) plunged 15.7%, losing the most of any S&P 500 stock. The company posted lower-than-expected sales and profits for the first quarter, and Enphase's CEO noted that tariffs could weigh on future results. In particular, the company sources battery cell packs from China and anticipates that levies on these imports will pressure its gross margins in upcoming quarters.

Although heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) specialist Lennox International (LII) topped quarterly sales and profit estimates, its full-year guidance fell short of consensus forecasts, and its shares fell 9.0%. The CEO stressed that Lennox is adapting to the challenging economic environment with pricing adjustments as it aims to maintain the stability of its supply chain.

Shares of oilfield services and energy technology firm Baker Hughes (BKR) sank 6.4% on Wednesday following a mixed quarterly earnings release. Although profits topped forecasts, revenues came in below expectations. The company faces an uncertain macroeconomic backdrop and softness in oil prices that could hinder its clients' production activities.
titles: S&P 500 Gains and Losses Today: Tech Stocks Jump as Trump Softens Stance on Fed and Trade
summary: On April 23, 2025, the S&P 500 rose 1.7% following statements from the White House indicating stability at the Federal Reserve and potential easing of U.S.-China trade tensions. Amphenol's strong quarterly results led its shares to jump 8.2%, marking the top performance in the S&P 500 for the day. In contrast, Enphase Energy's shares fell 15.7% due to lower-than-expected sales and profits, along with concerns over future tariffs affecting its gross margins. The technology sector saw significant gains, with optimism around U.S.-China trade relations contributing to the positive movement. Other

titles: Trump to exempt carmakers from some US tariffs
summary: Following intense lobbying efforts from industry executives, the President has decided to retreat from a previously announced policy decision. This marks a significant change in direction for the administration, influenced directly by the business sector's input.

title: Bessent warns mutual de-escalation required in US-China trade war
snippets: Treasury secretary denies reports Washington will make unilateral cuts to tariffs
titles: Bessent warns mutual de-escalation required in US-China trade war
summary: The Treasury Secretary has officially denied reports claiming that Washington plans to unilaterally reduce tariffs. This statement clarifies the current stance of the U.S. government regarding tariff policy, indicating no such cuts will be made independently.

title: Uncertainty About Tariffs Has Become 'Pervasive' In The Economy, Fed Finds
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Uncertainty about tariffs became "pervasive" among business and community leaders around the country in April, according to a report by the Federal Reserve.
  • Business leaders said uncertainty is making it hard to invest and plan for the future.
  • The report highlighted the "on the ground" consequences of President Donald Trump's rapidly shifting trade war.


Everyone is talking about tariffs, and no one quite knows what to make of them.

That's according to the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" published Wednesday. The report showed that among business and community leaders around the country, uncertainty about tariffs intensified in April as President Donald Trump steered his trade war in unpredictable directions. Some businesses braced for price increases from the import taxes, some prepared for layoffs, and some found themselves unable to make plans.

The Beige Book, a compilation of reports from business, nonprofit, and community leaders in local Fed districts around the country, gave a snapshot of how Trump's trade policies are affecting Main Street.

"Economic activity was little changed since the previous report, but uncertainty around international trade policy was pervasive across reports," Fed economists wrote.

April's report showed worries about tariffs have ramped up from an already high level in March. The reports mentioned "uncertainty" or a variation 89 times in April, up from 47 in March. "Tariffs" came up 107 times, up from 49. By contrast, in April 2024, when tariffs were just a gleam in then-candidate Trump's eye, "uncertainty" came up 13 times and tariffs not at all.

Experts have long warned that Trump's on-again, off-again campaign of imposing import taxes could stifle the economy by forcing businesses to delay making investments, and the report showed that those warnings are starting to come true, especially in the Richmond district.

"Several contacts put investments on hold due to increased uncertainty," the report said. "A military equipment manufacturer reported conditions being 'too chaotic' to make any decisions on future investments."

In Atlanta, "Contacts in lumber and wood products manufacturing experienced slowing demand amid ambiguity surrounding tariffs—one firm noted having 'zero faith in even a 6-month forecast,' and that the biggest hurdle to expansion and mergers and acquisitions was not knowing how trade policy will settle out."

It was the same story all across the country, with people in the construction and real estate business in Minnesota telling the Fed: “New projects have dried up completely in the first quarter. ...Uncertainty and chaos at the federal level has frozen pretty much all activity.” Another said "clients are hesitant to proceed with design until some sort of certainty and predictability comes back.”
titles: Uncertainty About Tariffs Has Become 'Pervasive' In The Economy, Fed Finds
summary: In April 2025, a Federal Reserve report, known as the Beige Book, highlighted widespread uncertainty among U.S. business and community leaders regarding tariffs, attributing this to President Donald Trump's unpredictable trade policies. This uncertainty has made it difficult for businesses to invest and plan for the future, with some preparing for price increases, layoffs, and putting investments on hold. The report, summarizing feedback from various sectors across the country, noted a significant increase in mentions of "uncertainty" and "tariffs" compared to previous months, indicating growi

title: Engineers print synthetic 'metamaterials' that are both strong and stretchy
snippets: Engineers have fabricated a metamaterial that is not only strong but also stretchy. Their new method could enable stretchable ceramics, glass, and metals, for tear-proof textiles or stretchy semiconductors.
titles: Engineers print synthetic 'metamaterials' that are both strong and stretchy
constructiveness_reason: This story highlights an innovation in the field of engineering. It provides empowering knowledge about the potential applications of this new technology.
summary: Engineers developed a new metamaterial with both strength and elasticity, opening possibilities for creating stretchable ceramics, glass, metals, and tear-proof textiles. This advancement could also lead to the development of stretchable semiconductors, enhancing the durability and flexibility of materials in various applications.

title: World on course to trigger multiple climate 'tipping points' unless action accelerates
snippets: Multiple climate 'tipping points' are likely to be triggered if global policies stay on their current course, new research shows.
titles: World on course to trigger multiple climate 'tipping points' unless action accelerates
constructiveness_reason: This story provides valuable information about the urgency of climate action. It increases awareness about the potential catastrophic impacts of climate change.
summary: New research indicates that if global policies do not change, several climate 'tipping points' are likely to be reached. These tipping points represent critical thresholds that, once crossed, could lead to significant and potentially irreversible changes in the climate system.

title: Can climate science attribute economic damage to major polluters?
snippets: Climate researchers argue their science has advanced enough to directly link emissions from particular companies to damages from specific extreme weather events
titles: Can climate science attribute economic damage to major polluters?
summary: Climate researchers have developed their science to the point where they can now directly associate emissions from specific companies with damages caused by certain extreme weather events. This advancement allows for a more precise understanding of the impact of individual corporate activities on climate-related disasters.

title: First evidence of gladiator fight with lion seen in Roman-era skeleton
snippets: A man who lived in Roman-occupied Britain was bitten by a big cat, probably in a gladiator arena, an analysis of his remains has revealed
titles: First evidence of gladiator fight with lion seen in Roman-era skeleton
summary: An analysis of remains has shown that a man from Roman-occupied Britain was likely bitten by a large cat, possibly during a gladiator event. This conclusion is based on the examination of his injuries.

title: Lyme disease treated with antibiotic that doesn't harm gut microbiome
snippets: Mice overcame a Lyme disease infection after being given an antibiotic that is often used for pneumonia, and its effect on their gut microbiomes was negligible
titles: Lyme disease treated with antibiotic that doesn't harm gut microbiome
summary: Mice infected with Lyme disease were successfully treated with an antibiotic commonly used for pneumonia, showing minimal impact on their gut microbiomes. This indicates the antibiotic's effectiveness against Lyme disease with little to no adverse effects on the gut's microbial balance.
